intro: Ophelia nuda, commonly known as the common water crowfoot, is a flowering plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, floating leaves and yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in shallow freshwater habitats such as ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams. Its leaves are usually divided into three parts, and it produces small, inconspicuous flowers that bloom in early spring. Ophelia nuda plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various aquatic organisms.
